Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: A Stochastic Approach for Radiative Forcing Studies Involving Black Carbon Aging/Life Cycle and Mountain Snow
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will use a stochastic approach based on probabilistic process to unlock the mystery of multiple internal mixing of uncoated black carbon (BC or soot) aggregates and coated BC core-shell spherical structures in the atmosphere, their associated role in cloud and precipitation processes, and the interaction of BC wet and dry depositions with surface snow layers. The fundamental principles of aerosol and cloud physics (deterministic process) cannot be applied to quantifying multiple internal mixing of uncoated/coated BC in snowflakes since many possibilities exist due to random collision and coalescence events. The subject has never been addressed in the literature. However, it is critically important in the understanding of snow albedo reduction over mountains in connection with the BC deposition from the atmosphere.

Intellectual Merit:
The research and subsequent results will for the first time provide models and datasets necessary to address a number of unsolved issues engendering new physical insights about the effects of atmospheric BC (uncoated aggregates and coated core-shell sphere) on cloud formation and precipitation processes and the consequence of wet and dry depositions of BC particles in forms of snowflakes and graupels onto 3-D and intense snow topography.

Broader Impacts:
The research efforts will add a new dimension to parameterization of BC-snow processes in regional and global climate models. The research will have a significant impact on a broad range of climate and atmospheric sciences, providing interactive BC-snow parameterization datasets based on the stochastic principle for reducing uncertainties in the projection and prediction of surface temperature and water resources over mountainous areas by means of computer models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The support of the present NSF EAGER Program under Grant 1523296 continues to be related to the PI’s pursuit of fundamental research and academic excellence in the areas of radiative transfer in black carbon (BC) coupled with ice crystals and surface snow grains, with application to weather and climate models and remote sensing exploration. The prime objectives of our research work are (1) to develop BC aging model in the atmosphere for light absorption and scattering computations, (2) to formulate a stochastic approach to understand and quantify BC internal mixing in ice and snow, and (3) to validate a unified theory for light scattering by ice particles innovated by the PI for radiative transfer through the BC-ice-snow system for use in land surface models.

The theoretical and computational efforts developed herein are associated with the investigation of aerosol-snow-albedo feedback recognized to be the most significant positive amplification of surface temperature increase and snowmelt in regions comprising mountains and snow such as the Tibetan Plateau and Sierra Nevada. Thus, this research endeavor will have important wide-reaching impacts on atmospheric and climate sciences in the context of providing interactive snow albedo datasets, including the mixing states of BC with the objective of reducing uncertainties in the projection and prediction of surface temperatures and water resources in terms of drought and flooding by means of regional and global environmental models. Moreover, the development of the stochastic approach for the mixing state of BC in snow grains (dirty snow) is innovative and represents a paradigm shift in the field of atmospheric physics.

In addition to the research accomplishments presented above, this NSF Grant also provided excellent opportunities to integrate research and education in the discipline of atmospheric sciences. This project has been able to support an excellent graduate student, Cenlin He, who has worked closely with the PI on radiative transfer in absorbing aerosols and snow grains. Through this research, he and other students related to the program have received critical thinking, creativity, and collaboration/communication skills, which will greatly benefit them in their academic and research pursuits. The PI wishes to point out that through the support of NSF in past years, he has had the privilege and good fortune of working with a number of bright and talented graduate students who have become successful academicians and researchers.
